learning.resource_discovery_description:
Before creating an IoT Job, we need to discover available thing groups and packages.
Thing groups define which devices will receive the job. For OTA jobs, we also need
packages from the Software Package Catalog. Other job types can work with thing
groups alone, making them more flexible for various device operations.

ðŸ”„ NEXT: We will scan for available thing groups and IoT packages in your account
learning.job_type_title: Job Type Selection - Choosing Operation Type
learning.job_type_description:
AWS IoT Jobs support two main operation types:
â€¢ OTA Updates: Firmware deployment with AWS IoT Software Package Catalog integration
â€¢ Custom Operations: Any device-specific commands or workflows with custom job documents

ðŸ”„ NEXT: We will select the job type and configure the operation
learning.target_config_description:
Now we'll configure job targets, execution parameters, and advanced settings.
Advanced configurations include rollout rates, retry policies, abort criteria,
and timeout settings. These ensure reliable job execution across large fleets
with proper error handling and performance optimization.

learning.job_creation_description:
We'll now create the {} job with all configured settings.
The job will be deployed to the selected thing groups with the specified
rollout, retry, and abort configurations. Devices will receive the job
document and execute the defined operations according to the job parameters.

learning.rollout_config_description:
Rollout configuration controls how quickly jobs are deployed across your fleet:
â€¢ Simple Rate Limiting: Set maximum executions per minute (e.g., 50 devices/min)
â€¢ Exponential Rollout: Start slow, increase rate based on success criteria

Exponential rollout is safer for large fleets - it starts with a small number of devices,
monitors success rates, and gradually increases deployment speed. This prevents
widespread failures from bad firmware or configuration changes.
learning.execution_rate_description:
Execution rate settings control how fast individual devices process jobs:
â€¢ Max Executions Per Minute: Prevents overwhelming your IoT infrastructure
â€¢ Exponential Rate: Gradually increases processing speed based on success

These settings are different from rollout config - rollout controls how many devices
get the job, while execution rate controls how fast each device processes it.
Proper rate limiting prevents API throttling and ensures stable job execution.
learning.abort_config_description:
Abort criteria automatically cancel jobs when failure rates exceed thresholds:
â€¢ Failure Threshold: Percentage of devices that must fail before abort (e.g., 10%)
â€¢ Minimum Executions: Number of devices to test before applying threshold
â€¢ Failure Types: FAILED, REJECTED, TIMED_OUT, or ALL

This prevents bad firmware or configurations from spreading across your entire fleet.
For example: 'Cancel job if >10% of devices fail after testing on at least 5 devices'
Essential for production deployments to minimize blast radius of failures.
learning.timeout_config_description:
Timeout settings prevent job executions from running indefinitely:
â€¢ In-Progress Timeout: Maximum time a device can spend processing a job
â€¢ Prevents devices from getting stuck in IN_PROGRESS state
â€¢ Automatically marks stuck executions as TIMED_OUT

Typical values: 60 minutes for firmware updates, 10 minutes for configuration changes.
Without timeouts, stuck devices can prevent job completion and waste resources.
Essential for maintaining fleet health and job lifecycle management.
learning.target_selection_description:
Target selection determines how jobs handle devices added to thing groups after job creation:
â€¢ CONTINUOUS: Automatically includes new devices added to target groups (recommended)
â€¢ SNAPSHOT: Only targets devices that existed in groups at job creation time

CONTINUOUS jobs are ideal for dynamic fleets where devices are frequently added,
while SNAPSHOT jobs provide predictable, fixed target lists for controlled deployments.
